2434129272.given_title: How to Win Games and Beat People (Ep. 247 Rebroadcast)
2434129272.resolved_title: How to Win Games and Beat People (Ep. 247 Rebroadcast)
2434129272.excerpt: Games are as old as civilization itself, and some people think they have huge social value regardless of whether you win or lose. Tom Whipple is not one of those people. That’s why he consulted an army of preposterously overqualified experts to find the secret to winning any game.

1.caption: Games are fun, but winning is better.

3313762098.given_title: Why Lichess will always be free. | Blog • lichess.org
3313762098.resolved_title: Why Lichess will always be free.
3313762098.excerpt: Most “free” websites subsist by selling ads or selling user data. Others do it by putting all the good stuff behind paywalls. Lichess doesn’t do any of that and never will. Almost 6 years ago, Lichess founder Thibault explained why Lichess is free - and what that means.

2399584030.excerpt: It’s a cold night in January 2012 and Peter Armenia is sitting on a Flushing-bound seven train, anticipating culture shock. For two decades, Armenia has played the ancient Chinese game of go, always wondering how his skills would hold up at a traditional Asian club.

3356001484.given_title: The UX of video game tutorials. What decisions a designer will run into… |
3356001484.resolved_title: The UX of video game tutorials
3356001484.excerpt: For a long time, it has been customary for tutorials to be a part of the First Time User Experience (FTUE). Usually, this meant that the journey would start from installing the game, followed by a rundown of the UI, adjusting preliminary settings, and being thrown into a tutorial.

1969860711.excerpt: Draughts is a funky little café tucked into a railway arch in Islington, in north London. It has exposed brick walls, a bar stocked with trendy craft beers and a selection of comfy chairs. The toast is artisanal and the avocados are smashed.

3989925753.excerpt: It is a truth universally acknowledged that Monopoly, patented on December 31, 1935 by Charles B. Darrow, is not a game: It’s a world.

2.caption: Charles B. Darrow is credited with inventing Monopoly as we know it today, based on real locations in Atlantic City, New Jersey. Bettmann/Getty Images

3.caption: The Landlord’s Game, on which Monopoly is based, has a very different philosophy. It educated about taxes and criticized the landlords. Thomas Forsyth/LandlordsGame.Info

4.caption: Marven Gardens, New Jersey, notably spelled differently than the yellow property in the game. Parker Brothers apologized to residents for the error

5.caption: Monopoly was first introduced to America in 1935, but its roots go deeper. Boon Leng Teo/Dreamstime

672976814.excerpt: When I was in ninth grade, back in 1970, we finished our geometry textbook six weeks before the end of the school year and spent the final grading period studying our math teacher’s principal extracurricular passion, which was bridge.

2.caption: In the nineteen-forties, bridge was played in two-fifths of American homes, but its complexity may be a barrier to a modern resurgence.JULES FEIFFER

1319170.excerpt: The Pagat website was founded in 1995. Its aim is to document the rules of traditional card and domino games for the benefit of players who would like to broaden their knowledge and try out unfamiliar games. It takes its name from the Pagat, the lowest trump in the Central European game of Tarock.

3843967049.excerpt: Play can be a great shortcut to bonding. But I’d rather just have a conversation. Several years ago, I moved to a small town in eastern Pennsylvania, and a co-worker invited me over for a classic social tradition: a game night. I don’t like board games.

2.caption: Illustration by Matt Chase / The Atlantic. Source: Getty.
